revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Romesh Ranganathan | caption = Ranganathan at the 2013 [[National Federation of Retail Newsagents|NFRN]] Awards | birth_name = Jonathan Romesh Ranganathan<ref name="auto"/> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|1|30}}<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=http://miner8.com/en/62008|title=Romesh Ranganathan}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Crawley]], [[West Sussex]], [[England]] | spouse = Leesa Ranganathan<ref name="auto"/> | children = Theo (9), Charlie (7), Alex (5)<ref>https://www.sundaypost.com/in10/chat/favourite-holiday-comedian-romesh-ranganathan-loved-madness-magic-algarve/</ref> | family = | website = {{Official URL}} }} '''Jonathan Romesh Ranganathan''' (born January 30, 1978) is a British stand-up comedian and actor. He was nominated for Best Newcomer at the 2013 [[Edinburgh Comedy Awards]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/woman/celeb-news/comedy-awards-shortlist-unveiled-29518008.html |title=Comedy awards shortlist unveiled |newspaper=[[Irish Independent]] |date=21 August 2013 |accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> He has made multiple appearances on comedy panel shows and in 2016, he co-presented ''[[It's Not Rocket Science (TV series)|It's Not Rocket Science]]'', alongside [[Rachel Riley]] and [[Ben Miller]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/story/000001262/ |title=Stand Up for the Week announces new line-up |date=7 October 2013 |publisher=[[British Comedy Guide]] |accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> He is known for his [[deadpan]] comedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wscountytimes.co.uk/what-s-on/entertainments/review-russell-kane-romesh-ranganathan-and-charlie-baker-at-christ-s-hospital-1-6642500|title=Review: Russell Kane, Romesh Ranganathan and Charlie Baker at Christ’s Hospital|last=Tamplin|first=Harley|date=19 March 2015|work=West Sussex County Times|accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref>
He is a regular panellist on ''[[The Apprentice: You're Fired!]]'', and was formerly a regular on ''[[Play to the Whistle]]'' and the eleventh series of ''[[The Museum of Curiosity]]''. In 2016, he completed his first major tour, Irrational Live, in which he performed in some iconic venues such as the Hammersmith Apollo. This tour was also released as a DVD. Ranganathan will also join ''[[A League of Their Own (UK game show)|A League of Their Own]]'' as a regular panellist in 2018, replacing [[Jack Whitehall]].
==Career== Ranganathan started performing as a comedian whilst working as a mathematics teacher at [[Hazelwick School]] in [[Crawley]], and [[The Beacon School, Banstead]], Surrey.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.kentlive.news/news/celebs-tv/7-famous-people-who-you-506152|title=7 famous people who you may not have realised went to school in Crawley|last=Truelove|first=Sam|date=3 October 2016|work=Kent Live|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref>
Ranganathan started presenting ''[[Newsjack]]'' on [[Radio 4 Extra]] in March 2014.<ref>{{BBC programme|id=b03wtj3x|title=Newsjack}}</ref>
He appeared on ''[[The Great British Bake Off: An Extra Slice]]'' in 2014, during which he presented his homemade vegan chocolate brownies. Ranganathan is a [[vegan]], having been a vegetarian up until 2013.<ref>{{BBC programme|id=b04gb578|title=Edinburgh Comedy Fest Live 2014, Part 2}}</ref>
Ranganathan has guested on multiple episodes of ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats Does Countdown]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.channel4.com/programmes/8-out-of-10-cats-does-countdown/on-demand/60792-005 |title=8 Out of 10 Cats Does Countdown |publisher=Channel 4}}</ref> He has also appeared on ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie to You?]]'', ''[[Holby City]]'', ''[[Soccer AM]]'', ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]'', ''[[Sweat the Small Stuff]]'', ''[[The Last Leg]]'', ''[[Virtually Famous]]'', ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', ''[[QI]]'' and ''[[Mock the Week]]''. He was a regular contestant on the first series of ''[[Taskmaster (TV series)|Taskmaster]]'' and also appeared in the third episode of ''[[Jon Richardson Grows Up]]''.
He also performed at [[The Royal Variety Performance]] in 2015.
In 2015, he presented a series for [[BBC Three]], ''[[Asian Provocateur]]'', in which he travelled to [[Sri Lanka]] to explore his ancestral country.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/sep/30/asian-provocateur-romesh-ranganathan-in-sri-lanka|title=Romesh Ranganathan: ‘I was a bumbling Englishman in a Sri Lankan disguise’|work=The Guardian}}</ref> In October 2016, the second series was aired in which Ranganathan and his mother travel to North America to meet more of his relatives.
He also joined ''[[The Apprentice: You're Fired!]]'' in 2015 as a regular panellist. The show is a spin-off from ''[[The Apprentice (UK TV series)|The Apprentice]]''. In December 2015, he appeared in [[Josh Widdicombe]]'s self-titled sitcom, ''[[Josh (TV series)|Josh]]''. In 2016, he co-presented ''[[It's Not Rocket Science (TV series)|It's Not Rocket Science]]'', a new entertainment series for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], alongside [[Ben Miller]] and [[Rachel Riley]]. In 2017, he became the eleventh co-presenter to [[John Lloyd (producer)|John Lloyd]] on the BBC Radio series ''[[The Museum of Curiosity]]''.
On February, 9, 2018, it was announced that Ranganthan will join Season 13 of [[A_League_of_Their_Own_(UK_game_show)|A League of Their Own (UK game show)]] in 2018.<ref>https://www.radiotimes.com/news/2018-02-09/romesh-ranganathan-to-replace-jack-whitehall-on-a-league-of-their-own/</ref>
Romesh also has starred in his own 10 episode docu-comedy called [[Just_Another_Immigrant|Just Another Immigrant]] that premiered on [[Showtime_(TV_network)|Showtime]] June 8, 2018.
==Personal life== [[File:Romesh Ranganathan in 2015.jpg|thumb|Romesh Ranganathan in 2015]]
Ranganathan was raised in [[Crawley]], [[West Sussex]]. He is married and has three children. In 2014, Ranganathan's wife, Leesa, was admitted to the [[Edinburgh Royal Infirmary]] during The [[Edinburgh Fringe Festival]] where Ranganathan was appearing, and gave birth to their son.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.crawleyobserver.co.uk/news/local/comic-romesh-celebrates-success-and-birth-of-a-son-1-6331462 |title=Comic Romesh celebrates success and birth of a son |date=3 October 2014 |newspaper=Crawley Observer |accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref>
Prior to his comedy career, he was a freestyle rapper under rap name "Ranga" and once reached the finals of the UK freestyle competition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.londonisfunny.com/the-spotlight-on-romesh-ranganathan/ |title=The Spotlight on ... Romesh Ranganathan |work=''londonisfunny.com'' |date=11 November 2011 |accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref>
Ranganathan studied Mathematics at Birkbeck College, [[University of London]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unipaper.co.uk/article/romesh-ranganathan-i-was-a-proper-wannabe-rudeboy-at-university|title= Romesh Ranganathan: I was a proper wannabe rudeboy at university |website=www.unipaper.co.uk}}</ref> He subsequently taught Maths at [[Hazelwick School]] in [[Crawley]] before becoming a professional comedian in 2012. His wife was a Drama teacher at Hazelwick.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.crawleynews.co.uk/Crawley-teacher-comedian-supported-Ricky-Gervais/story-20467062-detail/story.html |title=Former Crawley teacher now a comedian who has supported Ricky Gervais and appeared on Live at the Apollo |work=Crawley News |date=20 January 2014 |accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref>
He is of [[Sri Lankan Tamil people|Sri Lankan]] [[Tamil people|Tamil]] descent<ref>{{cite web|last=Hodges |first=Michael |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-10-07/9-things-romesh-ranganathan-learnt-when-his-mum-took-him-on-a-cultural-crash-course-to-sri-lanka |title=''Asian Provocateur'': What comic Romesh Ranganathan learnt about Sri Lanka in his new BBC3 show |work=[[Radio Times]] |date=7 October 2015 |accessdate=24 March 2017}}</ref> and a keen supporter of [[Arsenal F.C.]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/tvandshowbiz/2974180/romesh-ranganathan-comedian-play-to-the-whistle|title= Who is Romesh Ranganathan? Stand up comedian and regular panellist on Play to the Whistle|date=20 January 2015|newspaper=The Sun|access-date=2 August 2017}}</ref>
Ranganathan is a [[vegan]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Alice|title=Soya think you're funny? Introducing the UK's first Vegan Comedy Festival|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/news/soya-think-youre-funny-introducing-the-uks-first-vegan-comedy-festival-10042349.html|accessdate=22 October 2015|work=[[The Independent]]|date=12 February 2015}}</ref> and was raised in the [[Hindu]] faith.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/romeshranga/status/337328681712222208|title=Romesh Ranganathan on Twitter|newspaper=Twitter|access-date=4 January 2017}}{{Primary source inline|date=December 2017}}</ref> His mother has said that he "always prays before he leaves the home",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/tv/entries/e2d50d79-d452-4b18-8938-6a6d3d52670b|title=Romesh Ranganathan proves even TV comedians get embarrassed by their mums|date=1 October 2015|website=TV blog |publisher=BBC |access-date=4 January 2017}}</ref> although Ranganathan describes himself as "not massively spiritual".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2015-10-07/9-things-romesh-ranganathan-learnt-when-his-mum-took-him-on-a-cultural-crash-course-to-sri-lanka|title=9 things Romesh Ranganathan learnt when his mum took him on a cultural crash course to Sri Lanka|newspaper=Radio Times|access-date=4 January 2017}}</ref> He suffers from a right-sided [[Ptosis (eyelid)|ptosis]] (drooping eyelid), which he describes as a "lazy eye".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/topics/life/culture/article/2017/03/21/teaching-maths-performing-comedy-prince-harry-meet-romesh-ranganathan|title=From teaching maths to performing comedy for Prince Harry: meet Romesh Ranganathan|work=Topics|access-date=2018-03-14|language=en}}</ref>
His father died December 13, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/notice/L-60080-1542235|title=Details of the Deceased|date=7 March 2012|website=The Gazette|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>

BBC announces new popular factual and factual entertainment commissions - Media Centre|website=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> | [[BBC Two]] | Presenter | 1 series |- | 2018 | ''Judge Romesh''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://rts.org.uk/article/uktv-announces-new-commissions-2018|title=UKTV announces new commissions for 2018|date=23 January 2018|publisher=}}</ref> | [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]] | Presenter | Upcoming series |- |}
